DOC.HEAD: `Human Chain' Almost Surrounds City, Police Charge Twice
DOC.TEXT: Police and border troops used nightsticks and fired rubber bullets, tear gas and water cannons to disperse some of the thousands of people demonstrating for peace in Jerusalem's Old City today. At least 13 people were injured. Police arrested 50 people, according to Israel radio. Police said some demonstrators shouted pro-Palestinian slogans, setting off two charges by policemen into largely Palestinian groups. Some demonstrators shouted ``Palestine is Arab!'' and the Moslem rallying cry ``Allahu Akbar'' _ ``God is great!'' For the most part, however, the Israeli, European and Palestinian participants in the peace chain joined in chants of ``We want peace'' and carried balloons with the rally's slogan, ``1990 _ Time for Peace.'' Some 15,000 people, about a third more than organizers had expected, turned out for the ``human chain'' around the stone walls of Jerusalem's Old City. Twelve hundred people came from Europe for the rally, most of them Italians. The crowd probably could have encircled the wall of the Old City, a distance of more than 4,000 yards. But participants were unevenly distributed, with the activists five deep in some areas and up to a dozen yards apart in others. After the activists linked hands, thousands of balloons were released into the air to drift over the city. People stood silently for about 15 minutes, then some participants broke into a rousing version of ``We Shall Overcome'' and chanted ``two states for two people.'' Rally organizers said the goal was to prove that dialogue between Israelis and Palestinians can lead to peace in the Middle East. The rally was sponsored by Italian peace groups, Israel's Peace Now and Palestinian activists. Faisal Husseini, a Palestinian leader in Jerusalem, complained that army roadblocks on the outskirts of Jerusalem kept many Palestinian from attending. ``I know that if the road were opened, we would have had double or triple the number you are seeing,'' Husseini told reporters as he joined the gathering. He described it as ``a very historic moment'' and added that it should be a message for Israelis to look at the Palestinian as an individual and ``learn that you can build peace with him.'' A woman's peace march on Friday, also part of the ``1990 _ Time for Peace'' program, was broken up by police firing tear gas and swinging nightsticks after an outlawed Palestinian flag was raised.
